<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_socket_set_nodelay_:
```c
int
MHD_socket_set_nodelay_ (MHD_socket sock,
                         bool on)
{
#ifdef TCP_NODELAY
  {
    const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ off_val = 0;
    const MHD_SCKT_OPT_BOOL_ on_val = 1;
    /* Disable Nagle's algorithm for normal buffering */
    return setsockopt (sock,
                       IPPROTO_TCP,
                       TCP_NODELAY,
                       (const void *) ((on) ? &on_val : &off_val),
                       sizeof (on_val));
  }
#else
  (void) sock;
  return 0;
#endif /* TCP_NODELAY */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in the supplied function shows direct or indirect self-calls. The only function call present is setsockopt, which is an external library/system call and not MHD_socket_set_nodelay_; there are no function-pointer invocations, callbacks, or other calls that could hide an indirect call to MHD_socket_set_nodelay_. The preprocessor conditional controls inclusion of setsockopt usage only; it does not introduce any recursion. The remaining statements are local constant declarations, a ternary selecting a pointer, a cast, sizeof, a (void) cast to suppress unused-parameter warning, and return statements — none of which can cause the function to call itself. Therefore no fragments require investigation for Rule 17.2.
